markdown="[Back to Explore](https://www.alltrails.com/explore)\n\n# Angels Landing Trail\n\n4.9\n\n(37,440 reviews)\n\n·\n\nStrenuous\n\n·\n\n[Zion National Park](https://www.alltrails.com/parks/us/utah/zion-national-park)\n\nOverviewConditionsReviewsHit the trailNearby\n\nGet directionsHit the trail\n\n![Second photo of Angels Landing Trail in Zion National Park](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%%3D&w=3840&q=75)\n\n59,617 photos\n\n4.7miLength\n\n1,738ftElevation gain\n\nOut & back\n\nThe Angels Landing Trail is a technical route in Zion National Park with steep drop-offs, scrambles, and very narrow sections. Though it is protected by chains in many sections, the final push to the landing is considered Class 3 terrain due to the exposure, short steep scrambles, and steep drop-offs on either side. The incredible views of Zion Canyon make this hike the most popular in Zion.\n\nYou'll start by parking at The Grotto Trailhead or taking the West Rim Shuttle to The Grotto shuttle stop. You'll cross a bridge over the Virgin River onto the West Rim Trail. The first few miles of this route along the West Rim Trail are on a paved path. Most of the path is sunny, but Refrigerator Canyon offers shade and often a cool breeze.\n\nEventually, you’ll come to Walter's Wiggles, a set of 21 switchbacks that take their name from Walter Ruesch, Zion National Park’s first superintendent. The section of the route follows a steep and narrow ridge from Scout Lookout to Angels Landing itself, a fantastic observation point 1500 feet above Zion Canyon. Anchored support chains are attached along some sections of the sheer cliff to assist your way up and down the carved steps. You are rewarded with an excellent view of the main canyon at the top.\n\nHeads up! It is a good idea to avoid standing near the edge at all times and avoid hiking this trail when it is wet, storming, or high winds are present. The route exposes hikers to steep drop-offs along cliff edges. You'll want to budget extra time for this route due to its technical sections. Although this is a popular hike all year round, the best time to hike this route is during the spring and fall. Summer afternoons can be dangerously hot, and winter weather conditions can cause the trail to be icy. The parking lot here fills up quickly so be sure to arrive early.\n\nGet directionsCustomize route\n\n3 alerts\n\nTop sights\n\n[Angels Landing\\\\\n\\\\\nPeak](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/angels-landing) [Zion Canyon\\\\\n\\\\\nValley](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/springdale/zion-canyon) [Scout Lookout\\\\\n\\\\\nViewpoint](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/springdale/scout-lookout) Show more\n\nPreview![Plus badge image](https://d27scpai1jcyi9.cloudfront.net/trail-app-router/bccf086224ae1c4a92c5d0e36c3aca7c821e6e2d/_next/static/media/plus-full-light-text.ef713369.svg)\n\n© Mapbox© Maxar© OpenStreetMap\n\nPlay\n\nTop sights\n\n[Angels Landing\\\\\n\\\\\nPeak](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/angels-landing) [Zion Canyon\\\\\n\\\\\nValley](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/springdale/zion-canyon) [Scout Lookout\\\\\n\\\\\nViewpoint](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/springdale/scout-lookout) Show more\n\n## Plan your visit\n\nFee required\n\nDogs not allowed\n\nPartially paved\n\nScramble\n\nRocky\n\nRivers\n\nShow more\n\nTrailgoers are saying\n\n4.9\n\nHighlights include breathtaking views, well-maintained paths, and a rewarding summit experience. Challenges are steep inclines, narrow sections, and cold winds. Reviewers recommend early starts, gloves for cold, and good footwear.\n\nThis summary is AI-generated from trail reviews and won’t always be perfect.\n\nWas it helpful?\n\nYes\n\nNo\n\nShow all reviews\n\nWeather\n\n## Reviews\n\n4.9\n\n37,577 reviews42,081 activities\n\n| 5 |  |  |\n| 4 |  |  |\n| 3 |  |  |\n| 2 |  |  |\n| 1 |  |  |\n\nReview trail\n\nMark as completed·\n\nSuggest edit\n\nSearch reviews\n\nBegin typing to search, use the up and down arrow keys to navigate, press enter to select\n\nAllTrails sort\n\n[Melissa Leyba](https://www.alltrails.com/members/melissa-leyba-2)\n\nDec 14, 2025\n\nNot crowdedBathrooms availableGreat conditionsGreat views\n\nWe went early Saturday morning on December 14. When we entered Zion at around 7:45am, we didn’t have to pay. When we reached the parking lot, the rangers helped us find where to park (there’s a small parking lot and a dirt parking lot available). It was really cold and windy at points throughout the hike but once we got to the top, it was sunny and a light breeze. I highly recommend wearing gloves as well as something to head and face warm! The wind combined with cold weather can be brutal. Walking down, it started to warm up and the crowds of people picked up considerably. It was nice getting there early, as there weren’t people but i could see how going later could mean larger crowds.\n\n[Saman Motamed](https://www.alltrails.com/members/saman-motamed)\n\nDec 13, 2025\n\nNot crowdedGreat views\n\nThis hike is so much more enjoyable with less crowds since we did this in the off season and there is now a permit system (this was not the case last time I did this)! I’m not particularly a fan of heights yet I thoroughly enjoyed the views and the challenge! At no point did the trail feel unsafe to me if you’re taking your time! Again emphasis on the trail being less busy and how much more enjoyable that made it!\n\n[Ellen Ratcliff](https://www.alltrails.com/members/ellen-ratcliff-1)\n\nDec 10, 2025·Hiking\n\nEasy to parkNot crowdedBathrooms availableGreat conditions\n\nWe won the lottery on weather and crowds. We saw maybe 10 people on the trail proper and more as we got closer to the bottom.\n\nI’m someone who experiences physiologic shut down from heights and I was able to make it by keeping my eyes focused only on the ground right in front of me. Somewhere along the way during the chain section I started thinking, how the heck will I come down from here (I’m 50 and have had a knee replacement and need another one eventually)?\n\nIf you begin to do that, don’t worry - coming down is not so bad! Just focus on the 5 feet you live in and do it one step at a time.\n\nI can’t believe how well maintained the trail is and how perfect the weather can be even in December. Take gloves, those chains are COLD.\n\nDifficulty:Hard\n\n[Show activity](https://www.alltrails.com/explore/recording/morning-hike-at-angels-landing-trail-9e3aae2)\n\n[Megh Dedhia](https://www.alltrails.com/members/megh-dedhia)\n\nYesterday·Hiking\n\nEasy to parkBathrooms availableDog-friendlyGreat conditionsGreat views\n\nAmazing views, going uptil the scouts lookout is easy to moderate but angels landing trail is really tedious and technical. Chains help. Carry water and snacks!\n\nParking:Permit required, Free, Large lot\n\n![Photo 1 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n![Photo 2 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n![Photo 3 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n![Photo 4 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n![Photo 5 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n![Photo 6 of 6](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/trail-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)\n\n[Ravi Gupta](https://www.alltrails.com/members/ravi-gupta-6)\n\nYesterday·Hiking\n\nBathrooms availableGreat conditionsGreat views\n\nGo early to beat the traffic at the chains. If you want to miss the long lines of mediocre hikers going up the permitted route I would suggest leaving at 6:45 or 10 minutes before sunrise. (DO NOT ATTEMPT WITHOUT PERMIT) There was a couple that tried to beat the ranger by going up earlier without a permit and luckily ranger reggie stopped them on the way down, police were waiting by the time they got down the main hike with a 5000 dollar fine for each of them.\n\nDifficulty:Hard\n\n![Photo 1 of activity](https://www.alltrails.com/explore/recording/afternoon-hike-a068738)\n\n## Hit the trail\n\n## Frequently asked questions\n\n### What’s helpful to know about this trail?\n\nProceed cautiously on this 4.7-mile out-and-back trail near Springdale, Utah. Generally considered a highly challenging route, it should only be attempted by experienced adventurers. This is a very popular area for hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through November. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.\n\n### What are some of the facilities available for Angels Landing Trail?\n\nIn 1997 the shuttle system was established to eliminate traffic and parking problems & protect vegetation. It is recommended to take the shuttle to this popular trailhead.\n\n### What is the expected weather this week for Angels Landing Trail?\n\nExpected weather for Angels Landing Trail for the next 5 days is:\n\n- Mon, December 22 - 69 degrees/clear\n- Tue, December 23 - 64 degrees/drizzle\n- Wed, December 24 - 60 degrees/showers\n- Thu, December 25 - 51 degrees/showers\n- Fri, December 26 - 49 degrees/showers\n\n### Where is Angels Landing Trail located?\n\nAngels Landing Trail is a trail located in [Zion National Park](https://www.alltrails.com/parks/us/utah/zion-national-park).\n\n### Are dogs allowed on Angels Landing Trail?\n\nNo, dogs are not allowed on Angels Landing Trail.\n\n### When is the best time of year to hike Angels Landing Trail?\n\nMarch to November is the most popular time of year to visit Angels Landing Trail.\n\nShow more\n\n## Top trails nearby\n\n[Scout Lookout via West Rim Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/utah/scout-lookout-trail)\n\n[![Photo 1 of 1 [Pullout](https://www.alltrails.com/poi/us/utah/springdale/pullout)\n\nDownloadOpen map" html=None raw_html=None json=None summary=None metadata=DocumentMetadata(title='Angels Landing Trail, Utah - 37,440 Reviews, Map | AllTrails', description="• Fee Information: Zion National Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please see https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/fees.htm\n• Access Information: Zion National Park requires a permit to hike the Angels Landing trail. For more information, please visit: https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/angels-landing-hiking-permits.htm\n• Access Information: The Zion Canyon Scenic Drive is closed to private vehicles during the shuttle season. For more information, visit www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/zion-canyon-shuttle-system.htm\n\nThe Angels Landing Trail is a technical route in Zion National Park with steep drop-offs, scrambles, and very narrow sections. Though it is protected by chains in many sections, the final push to the landing is considered Class 3 terrain due to the exposure, short steep scrambles, and steep drop-offs on either side.  The incredible views of Zion Canyon make this hike the most popular in Zion.\n\nYou'll start by parking at The Grotto Trailhead or taking the West Rim Shuttle to The Grotto shuttle stop. You'll cross a bridge over the Virgin River onto the West Rim Trail. The first few miles of this route along the West Rim Trail are on a paved path. Most of the path is sunny, but Refrigerator Canyon offers shade and often a cool breeze.\n\nEventually, you’ll come to Walter's Wiggles, a set of 21 switchbacks that take their name from Walter Ruesch, Zion National Park’s first superintendent. The section of the route follows a steep and narrow ridge from Scout Lookout to Angels Landing itself, a fantastic observation point 1500 feet above Zion Canyon. Anchored support chains are attached along some sections of the sheer cliff to assist your way up and down the carved steps. You are rewarded with an excellent view of the main canyon at the top.\n\nHeads up! It is a good idea to avoid standing near the edge at all times and avoid hiking this trail when it is wet, storming, or high winds are present. The route exposes hikers to steep drop-offs along cliff edges. You'll want to budget extra time for this route due to its technical sections. Although this is a popular hike all year round, the best time to hike this route is during the spring and fall. Summer afternoons can be dangerously hot, and winter weather conditions can cause the trail to be icy. The parking lot here fills up quickly so be sure to arrive early.", url='https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/utah/angels-landing-trail', language='en', keywords=None, robots='follow', og_title='Angels Landing Trail', og_description="• Fee Information: Zion National Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please see https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/fees.htm\n• Access Information: Zion National Park requires a permit to hike the Angels Landing trail. For more information, please visit: https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/angels-landing-hiking-permits.htm\n• Access Information: The Zion Canyon Scenic Drive is closed to private vehicles during the shuttle season. For more information, visit www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/zion-canyon-shuttle-system.htm\n\nThe Angels Landing Trail is a technical route in Zion National Park with steep drop-offs, scrambles, and very narrow sections. Though it is protected by chains in many sections, the final push to the landing is considered Class 3 terrain due to the exposure, short steep scrambles, and steep drop-offs on either side.  The incredible views of Zion Canyon make this hike the most popular in Zion.\n\nYou'll start by parking at The Grotto Trailhead or taking the West Rim Shuttle to The Grotto shuttle stop. You'll cross a bridge over the Virgin River onto the West Rim Trail. The first few miles of this route along the West Rim Trail are on a paved path. Most of the path is sunny, but Refrigerator Canyon offers shade and often a cool breeze.\n\nEventually, you’ll come to Walter's Wiggles, a set of 21 switchbacks that take their name from Walter Ruesch, Zion National Park’s first superintendent. The section of the route follows a steep and narrow ridge from Scout Lookout to Angels Landing itself, a fantastic observation point 1500 feet above Zion Canyon. Anchored support chains are attached along some sections of the sheer cliff to assist your way up and down the carved steps. You are rewarded with an excellent view of the main canyon at the top.\n\nHeads up! It is a good idea to avoid standing near the edge at all times and avoid hiking this trail when it is wet, storming, or high winds are present. The route exposes hikers to steep drop-offs along cliff edges. You'll want to budget extra time for this route due to its technical sections. Although this is a popular hike all year round, the best time to hike this route is during the spring and fall. Summer afternoons can be dangerously hot, and winter weather conditions can cause the trail to be icy. The parking lot here fills up quickly so be sure to arrive early.", og_url='https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/utah/angels-landing-trail', og_image='https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v3/maps/346265104/share_image?image_type=default&photo_id=42787626&shape=rectangle&units=i', og_audio=None, og_determiner=None, og_locale=None, og_locale_alternate=None, og_site_name='AllTrails.com', og_video=None, favicon='https://www.alltrails.com/app-icon-16.png', dc_terms_created=None, dc_date_created=None, dc_date=None, dc_terms_type=None, dc_type=None, dc_terms_audience=None, dc_terms_subject=None, dc_subject=None, dc_description=None, dc_terms_keywords=None, modified_time=None, published_time=None, article_tag=None, article_section=None, source_url='https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/utah/angels-landing-trail', status_code=200, scrape_id='019b47b9-93da-71de-9ff6-b1cd517d9db5', num_pages=None, content_type='text/html; charset=utf-8', proxy_used='basic', timezone=None, cache_state='hit', cached_at='2025-12-22T19:29:03.483Z', credits_used=1, concurrency_limited=False, concurrency_queue_duration_ms=None, error=None, twitter:description="• Fee Information: Zion National Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please see https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/fees.htm\n• Access Information: Zion National Park requires a permit to hike the Angels Landing trail. For more information, please visit: https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/angels-landing-hiking-permits.htm\n• Access Information: The Zion Canyon Scenic Drive is closed to private vehicles during the shuttle season. For more information, visit www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/zion-canyon-shuttle-system.htm\n\nThe Angels Landing Trail is a technical route in Zion National Park with steep drop-offs, scrambles, and very narrow sections. Though it is protected by chains in many sections, the final push to the landing is considered Class 3 terrain due to the exposure, short steep scrambles, and steep drop-offs on either side.  The incredible views of Zion Canyon make this hike the most popular in Zion.\n\nYou'll start by parking at The Grotto Trailhead or taking the West Rim Shuttle to The Grotto shuttle stop. You'll cross a bridge over the Virgin River onto the West Rim Trail. The first few miles of this route along the West Rim Trail are on a paved path. Most of the path is sunny, but Refrigerator Canyon offers shade and often a cool breeze.\n\nEventually, you’ll come to Walter's Wiggles, a set of 21 switchbacks that take their name from Walter Ruesch, Zion National Park’s first superintendent. The section of the route follows a steep and narrow ridge from Scout Lookout to Angels Landing itself, a fantastic observation point 1500 feet above Zion Canyon. Anchored support chains are attached along some sections of the sheer cliff to assist your way up and down the carved steps. You are rewarded with an excellent view of the main canyon at the top.\n\nHeads up! It is a good idea to avoid standing near the edge at all times and avoid hiking this trail when it is wet, storming, or high winds are present. The route exposes hikers to steep drop-offs along cliff edges. You'll want to budget extra time for this route due to its technical sections. Although this is a popular hike all year round, the best time to hike this route is during the spring and fall. Summer afternoons can be dangerously hot, and winter weather conditions can cause the trail to be icy. The parking lot here fills up quickly so be sure to arrive early.", og:description="• Fee Information: Zion National Park charges a fee to enter. For more information, please see https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/fees.htm\n• Access Information: Zion National Park requires a permit to hike the Angels Landing trail. For more information, please visit: https://www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/angels-landing-hiking-permits.htm\n• Access Information: The Zion Canyon Scenic Drive is closed to private vehicles during the shuttle season. For more information, visit www.nps.gov/zion/planyourvisit/zion-canyon-shuttle-system.htm\n\nThe Angels Landing Trail is a technical route in Zion National Park with steep drop-offs, scrambles, and very narrow sections. Though it is protected by chains in many sections, the final push to the landing is considered Class 3 terrain due to the exposure, short steep scrambles, and steep drop-offs on either side.  The incredible views of Zion Canyon make this hike the most popular in Zion.\n\nYou'll start by parking at The Grotto Trailhead or taking the West Rim Shuttle to The Grotto shuttle stop. You'll cross a bridge over the Virgin River onto the West Rim Trail. The first few miles of this route along the West Rim Trail are on a paved path. Most of the path is sunny, but Refrigerator Canyon offers shade and often a cool breeze.\n\nEventually, you’ll come to Walter's Wiggles, a set of 21 switchbacks that take their name from Walter Ruesch, Zion National Park’s first superintendent. The section of the route follows a steep and narrow ridge from Scout Lookout to Angels Landing itself, a fantastic observation point 1500 feet above Zion Canyon. Anchored support chains are attached along some sections of the sheer cliff to assist your way up and down the carved steps. You are rewarded with an excellent view of the main canyon at the top.\n\nHeads up! It is a good idea to avoid standing near the edge at all times and avoid hiking this trail when it is wet, storming, or high winds are present. The route exposes hikers to steep drop-offs along cliff edges. You'll want to budget extra time for this route due to its technical sections. Although this is a popular hike all year round, the best time to hike this route is during the spring and fall. Summer afternoons can be dangerously hot, and winter weather conditions can cause the trail to be icy. The parking lot here fills up quickly so be sure to arrive early.", og:site_name='AllTrails.com', place:location:longitude='-112.95122', og:url='https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/utah/angels-landing-trail', fb:app_id='18128749820', og:image:width='640', og:title='Angels Landing Trail', og:image='https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v3/maps/346265104/share_image?image_type=default&photo_id=42787626&shape=rectangle&units=i', og:type='website', theme-color='#2b381f', og:image:alt='AllTrails', place:location:latitude='37.2591', og:image:secure_url='https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v3/maps/346265104/share_image?image_type=default&photo_id=42787626&shape=rectangle&units=i', copyright='© 2010-2025 AllTrails, LLC', twitter:title='Angels Landing Trail, Utah - 37,440 Reviews, Map | AllTrails', twitter:site='@AllTrails', twitter:card='summary_large_image', twitter:image:alt='AllTrails', og:image:height='640', revisit-after='3 days', facebook-domain-verification='6sh9vc7x1667ruajj38c5eumwnj4rb', twitter:image='https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v3/maps/346265104/share_image?image_type=default&photo_id=42787626&shape=rectangle&units=i', viewport=['width=device-width, initial-scale=1', 'width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0 viewport-fit=cover']) links=None images=None screenshot=None actions=None warning=None change_tracking=None branding=None
